body: @gwsshs22 Did you have a chance to look at the Travis CI problem?

@yunseong If the client uses `callback`, it's not going to call `get`. 
`callback` should be able to deliver the future's result and exception.

@bgchun I totally agree with you. Exceptions should be passed to the client even with callbacks. 
Also, `ExactlyOnceObserver` sounds great to me. Maybe we need a discussion via mailing list or JIRA?

Can you open a JIRA issue? Since it's specific to Vortex Future, we don't
need to discuss via our mailing list.

## 

Byung-Gon Chun

I opened REEF-1023(https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/REEF-1023).

What about @johnyangk's suggestion that having only one way to get the result/exception of `VortexFuture`? I think sometimes user might want to use `VortexFuture.get()` for simplicity. Any other opinion?

@yunseong We can merge this PR now, and then you can change this example to address the callback issue. Or we can wait for the callback issue to be addressed, update this PR, and merge it afterwards. How would you like to proceed?

@bgchun I just wanted to bring up what @johnyangk suggested. I think it's natural to have both methods.

For merging this, either way is fine with me. But this change has not been merged yet, so I think it'd be better to merge this after the callback issue is addressed.

Sounds good. Thanks.

I reproduced the error and confirmed that the change works both when building from the command line and from Visual Studio.
The tests pass, I'll merge.
@anupam128 had some reservations about using `DeploymentItem`, as it won't be available in xUnit. Doesn't this patch make the situation worse?
I'll merge.

Not really. We still need to figure out how to migrate DeploymentItem annotations to xUnit for tests which are already using it, in O.A.R.Tests\Functional and O.A.R.Tang.Tests. It's better to have more tests which we need to migrate than to have failing tests.
Thank you.
I changed the code according the comments and also rebased to the master.
The failure, `WatcherTest.testEventStream`, on one of Travis CI  is not relevant to this PR.
Thanks! I will test and merge.
I will test and merge.
How do we know that the change is successful? Run the tests in master and in this branch and compare that the same number of tests ran?
Yes. I ran tests from VS and tracked individual tests. xUnit tests are displayed in Test Explorer using fully qualified method name, so they are easy to distinguish from mstest ones.

@dongjoon-hyun, @markusweimer, @afchung 
I've updated the PR description and the code as per our discussion in JIRA. Could you please take a look?
Thank you @markusweimer !
Note that I haven't touched on the Driver restart & .NET bridge part as it'd be better for someone who is more knowledgeable to work on them. Feel free to create JIRA issues for those.

Did we decide to distinguish hard and soft preemption events or not? 
Does `PreemptedEvaluator` cover both?
@markusweimer I think @johnyangk rushed a bit since this issue has been blocking the progress of Vortex. Let's agree upon the API in JIRA before we consider this PR.
@bgchun Sounds good, let's discuss in JIRA regarding soft preemption.
Rebased.
@jwang98052 what's the status on your review of this PR?
@dongjoon-hyun Sure, I'll update the PR and rebase.
So we have decided to make ITask Disposable?
I will test and merge
@jwang98052 `ITask` has always been disposable, but there is ongoing discussion on the dev mailing list as to whether or not we want to remove it.

@dafrista @dongjoon-hyun An alternative is to create a ConfigurationModule class for `RemoteManager`, but I'm not sure if the complexity of `RemoteManager` is enough to justify this.
Overall though, I'm +1 for un-deprecating the constructor.

Got the following exception in test case TestPipelinedBroadcastAndReduceOnLocalRuntime in some of the machines:

ERROR: ExceptionCaught ObjectDisposedException encountered error [System.ObjectDisposedException: Cannot access a disposed object.
Object name: 'System.Net.Sockets.NetworkStream'.
   at System.Net.Sockets.NetworkStream.EndRead(IAsyncResult asyncResult)
   at System.Threading.Tasks.TaskFactory`1.FromAsyncTrimPromise`1.Complete(TInstance thisRef, Func`3 endMethod, IAsyncResult asyncResult, Boolean requiresSynchronization)

This will be caused if we are disposing the same stream or object twice. Since this PR is about  Dispose of Task object, it might be related.
@dongjoon-hyun Updated. Please have another look. Thanks!

Thank you, @afchung . I will. 

By the way, as you know, Apache REEF GitHub is changed an hours ago. I'm not sure that it has no side effects.
@jwang98052 I don't think they are related. I was able to repro the failure on a clean build. Could you verify? Thanks!

Agreed. @johnyangk can you please close the PR till it is ready for review again?

A way we've dealt with this challenge in the past is the "Inject-a-Factory" pattern: That way, defaults for all the parameters of `DefaultRemoteManager` can be injected into the `DefaultRemoteManagerFactory`. And that factory can have methods to pass in additional parameters to overwrite those defaults.

That requires the class and its factory to be in the same package, though. And the class needs to have a package-private constructor used by the factory. And at some place, `DefaultRemoteManagerFactory` needs to be bound to the interface `RemoteManagerFactory`.

I thought RemoteManager was on the way to this design?
Looks good, I'll merge
Looks good, I'll merge

@jwang98052 @beysims @anupam128 Since you're all more experienced in C# than I am, please have a look. I've ran all the tests on local and on HDInsight. Thanks!
I will review it.
@afchung I've looked through this change and it looks good. @bgchun Could you take another look?
@bgchun Could you kindly take a look at this, please? Thanks.

@afchung This looks good. I'd like to suggest one thing, though. Instead of taking the guava dependency, it'd be better to create our own `FutureCallback` in `o.a.r.vortex.api` without introducing the dependency.

@yunseong Overall, this looks good. I do have a question, though. 
Right now, we have only `taskletId`, but a tasklet can be executed multiple times. In other frameworks like Hadoop MR, multiple execution instances are differentiated by an attempt id. For us, this would be `taskletAttemptId`. Don't you think we need attempt ids?

@bgchun Thanks for the review! I left a question about your comment.

For `taskletAttemptId`, I think it will be very useful for retrying failed Tasklets or duplicate execution. I'll create a JIRA for that.
It looks good to me, I will test by generating web page and merge this.
@yunseong @bgchun Thanks for the review! I've addressed the comments and also switched to use threads for the callbacks for asynchronicity, please have another look. Thanks!
I'll do a pass.
It looks good to me. I'll test and merge this.
I've done a pass and left some broad feedback. Let me know when that has been addressed and I will do another one.

@afchung Having our own callback looks great! I have one question: would it be better to use `Executors` than creating `new Thread()`? I'm not sure the benefit though, because we create only one thread per callback. @bgchun What do you think?

@yunseong Good point. Each VortexFuture callback creates a thread, which seems to be heavy weight if we launch many tasklets. It'd be better to create a shared executor for handling the callbacks. The executor is shared among `VortexFuture`s. 
@afchung How does this sounds?
Sounds good. My original thought was that creating a thread for each tasklet doesn't seem to be too much, but perhaps using an Executor will be more efficient.
+1 for fixed number of threads, as many tasklets are expected.
It looks good to me. I'll test and merge this.
It looks good to me. The testsuites became more robust and some typos are fixed together. I'll test and merge this.

I couldn't figure out why the failures frequently occurred in Travis CI, but found the problematic part was suspending and resubmitting the Task. This PR removes that test code. This commit has been tested 5 times  using `git commit --amend; git push --force` and checked no failures occurred. Thanks.
@markusweimer  Updated
@shulmanb Can you close this PR, modify your commit message such that it fits the format [here](https://cwiki.apache.org/confluence/display/REEF/Contributing), and then re-open the PR? Thanks!

Thank you for investigating this issue, @gwsshs22.

I think you need to test on Docker because Travis CI uses Docker with 2 dedicated cores and 4GB of memory. You can not produce this problem in your high performance PC. Please refer the following link.
https://docs.travis-ci.com/user/migrating-from-legacy/#More-available-resources

In addition, in the similar previous issues, I used VM to simulate Apache Jenkins machines with limited resources, especially RAM. You can try VM, too.
Thanks @afchung. The change looks great to me. I left some minor comments (I left the comments at your forked branch, and wrote again. Sorry for the inconvenience).

Assumptions on this PR: Tasklet ID is unique, and each tasklet only matches to one `VortexFuture`. We can make changes to accommodate duplicate tasklets once [REEF-500](https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/REEF-500) is shaped up.
@yunseong @bgchun That's fair; I've made the changes, please have a look. Thanks!
